edu.nyu.cs.omnidroid.ui.simple
Class FactoryDynamicUI

java.lang.Object
  edu.nyu.cs.omnidroid.ui.simple.FactoryDynamicUI

public class FactoryDynamicUI
extends java.lang.Object

Static factory class for setting up a dynamic UI for every filter/action type. TODO: (markww) Refactor internal builder classes to use parent class for common tasks.

Nested Class Summary
static interface FactoryDynamicUI.DlgDynamicInput
          This interface must be implemented by DlgFilterInput so we can support adding dynamic UI elements to it based on the filter type chosen by the end user.
static interface FactoryDynamicUI.DlgPreserveState
          The DlgFilterInput instance will have to support UI state preservation between orientation changes, but the class won't know what its UI elements are.
static interface FactoryDynamicUI.InputDone
          The DlgFilterInput instance will have a member instance of this interface.
 
Method Summary
static void buildUIForFilter(FactoryDynamicUI.DlgDynamicInput dlg, ModelFilter modelFilter, DataType dataOld)
          For now we hard-code all the filters into this factory class.

Method Detail

buildUIForFilter

public static void buildUIForFilter(FactoryDynamicUI.DlgDynamicInput dlg,
                                    ModelFilter modelFilter,
                                    DataType dataOld)
For now we hard-code all the filters into this factory class. Eventually this should be changed to use some information from the database about filter attribute types to generate the required UI elements, instead of a large hard-coded if statement. The passed filter may already be a fully constructed instance, for example, if the user is editing a constructed filter instance in the UI. In that case, its data can be queried and used to pre-populate controls for end-user convenience.

Parameters:
dlg - Dialog interface
modelFilter - The model filter we want to try to fill.
dataOld - If we're modifying an existing filter, then this is the data the user had last set for it.
